title: Can you give a command to an AI and wait for it to do the job without explicitly telling it how to do it (machine learning, state of the art, AI)? - Quora

response.answer_text: Kind-of. What you’re referring to is more technically called unsupervised learning. Essentially the algorithm finds patterns in the data that it’s presented on the input. The most architecture case I’ve seen involves it copying the input to the output but being deliberately designed to have insufficient internal memory to reconstruct the input fully. It therefore has to recreate the input by essentially compressing it. Where it gets interesting is when you look at the compression algorithm it develops. It can do some interesting things, but often what it thinks is interested is less interesting to people. It’s also hard to fine-tune what it’s doing in situations where it is only somewhat interesting. I personally prefer reinforcement learning, in which you tell the algorithm that it has passed or failed but nothing else. There are a great many problems which cannot be solved by conventional algorithms but can be evaluated as passing. The extra input makes it much easier to guide this sort of algorithm into interesting behaviours.
